title: 111_s1699
content: The Act may be cited as the "Unemployment Compensation Extension Act of 2009" and includes provisions for additional emergency unemployment compensation. The "Unemployment Compensation Extension Act of 2009" provides for further additional emergency unemployment compensation to individuals in states with extended benefit periods, equal to 50% of their total regular compensation. The "Unemployment Compensation Extension Act of 2009" allows for additional emergency unemployment compensation to individuals in states with extended benefit periods, up to 13 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount. States are considered to be in an extended benefit period if certain conditions are met under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. The "Unemployment Compensation Extension Act of 2009" allows for extended compensation in states with extended benefit periods, regardless of state laws, with specific adjustments to the requirements. Additionally, states can pay extended compensation before emergency unemployment compensation under certain conditions. The "Unemployment Compensation Extension Act of 2009" provides extended compensation for at least 1 week of unemployment after the exhaustion of emergency unemployment compensation. There is a limitation on how many times an individual's account can be augmented under this provision. Amendments are made to the Non-Augmentation Rule and funds transfer sections of the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008. The amendments made by this section apply as if included in the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008, with no retroactive payments for weeks of unemployment before the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3 amends the Internal Revenue Code to change the FUTA surtax rate through 2010 and 2011. The amendments apply to wages paid after December 31, 2009. SEC. 4 requires reporting of the first day of earnings to the Directory of New Hires. The Social Security Act is amended to include reporting requirements for the date services were first performed by an employee. The effective date for these amendments is six months after the enactment of the Act. Compliance transition period may be required for State legislation. The State plan under part D of title IV of the Social Security Act must meet additional requirements imposed by an amendment. The plan is not considered to fail to meet these requirements until after the first day of the second calendar quarter following the first regular session of the State legislature that begins after the effective date of the amendment. If the State has a 2-year legislative session, each year is considered a separate regular session. SEC. 5 amends subsection (f) of section 6402 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by renumbering paragraphs. The amendment applies to refunds payable after the enactment of this Act.
